name: OpenNode

faqs.q: How does OpenNode's hosted checkout work?
faqs.a: When you create a charge, OpenNode returns a checkout URL that bundles the Lightning invoice and on-chain address so customers can choose their rail. That means you can simply redirect to checkout.opennode.com/{id} and append ln or hf query switches to shape the experience.

faqs.q: What fees does OpenNode charge for processing and withdrawals?
faqs.a: OpenNode charges around 1% for processing plus on-demand on-chain withdrawals, while scheduled weekly transfers stay free and Lightning withdrawals are free. You can choose instant payouts when speed matters or lean on scheduled moves if you want to avoid the extra fee.

faqs.q: How does OpenNode handle underpaid invoices?
faqs.a: You can set an underpayment tolerance so slightly short on-chain payments move forward automatically, and anything below the threshold is flagged as underpaid. Buyers can send the remaining sats or request a refund that returns their funds minus the 200 sat network fee, so you stay in control of the customer experience.

faqs.q: Can OpenNode pay Lightning invoices from my fiat balance?
faqs.a: Yes. Wire fiat into your OpenNode local currency wallet and initiate Lightning or on-chain payouts directly from that balance. The platform quotes the BTC amount and handles conversion so you can fund global payouts without ever holding bitcoin on your books.

Individual accounts submit government ID plus a fresh selfie, while businesses provide formation docs, ownership records, and proof of address so OpenNode can meet KYB obligations. That onboarding is what unlocks higher limits, fiat rails, and access to payout APIs.

description:
OpenNode is a Bitcoin-first payment processor that empowers businesses to accept and send Bitcoin—either on-chain or via Lightning—using simple plugins, hosted checkouts, or its developer-friendly API. Organisations that want a turnkey, compliant solution—especially mid-sized to large enterprises—can onboard easily with KYC and achieve global scale without building complex node infrastructure.

It offers instant, low-cost microtransactions with a focus on liquidity management, channel operations, and protocol support. For merchants, this means accessing Bitcoin payments both instantly and economically, alongside automatic settlement options in fiat or BTC. By abstracting away technical complexities like node handling, liquidity, and channel balance, OpenNode allows businesses to plug-and-play and scale efficiently.

It holds US regulatory licenses, manages KYC requirements, and maintains automated fiat conversions and payouts. This makes it ideal for businesses—especially blue-chip and enterprise-level—that require solid legal and financial backstops.

Their long-term vision is to see global businesses and platforms integrate Bitcoin payments as seamlessly as credit cards—secure, censorship-resistant, and frictionless—while pushing forward broader adoption of Bitcoin as a unit of exchange across borders and cultures.
recovery_method: 2FA-protected dashboard with support-verified resets for account admins.

tl_dr.best_for: Merchants who want compliant, turnkey Bitcoin acceptance without running their own nodes.
tl_dr.consider_if: You need to settle to fiat, Lightning, or on-chain from the same dashboard and API.
tl_dr.not_ideal_when: You must keep keys in-house or require zero processor fees.

howto.title: Set up your OpenNode payment stack

steps.title: 1. Create and verify your account
actions: Register on the dev or production dashboard and pick individual or business onboarding.
Upload the requested ID, selfie, and proof-of-address documents so compliance can unlock payouts.
Enable two-factor authentication before inviting teammates or generating live API keys.
steps.gotcha: Higher processing limits stay capped until KYB completes, so have incorporation and ownership docs ready.

steps.title: 2. Configure settlement & checkout
actions: Navigate to Settings > Payments to decide if you want to keep Bitcoin or auto-convert to local currency (USD, EUR, GBP).
Upload your store logo and cover image so the payment window matches your brand.
Create a Payment Button or Pos Link if you need a simple way to collect money without a full website.
steps.gotcha: Auto-conversion protects you from volatility but usually incurs a slightly higher fee (e.g., 1%) than keeping Bitcoin.

steps.title: 3. Connect your e-commerce store
actions: Click on Integrations to find the official plugin for your platform (WooCommerce, Shopify, Magento, etc.).
Generate an API Key in the dashboard and paste it into the plugin settings on your own website.
Run a test order on your shop to confirm the status updates from Pending to Paid automatically.
steps.gotcha: Ensure your website uses HTTPS (SSL); the secure connection is required for OpenNode to mark orders as paid.

steps.title: 4. Fund the fiat wallet and send payouts
actions: Contact support or use the live chat to wire fiat into your local currency wallet for payouts.
POST to /v2/withdrawals with auto_confirm set to false to preview the BTC quote before committing.
Confirm Lightning or on-chain payouts and monitor their status from the dashboard or webhook logs.
steps.gotcha: Preview quotes expire quickly, so confirm before the expiry timestamp if you want the same FX rate.

micro_faqs.q: Does the developer environment use real bitcoin?
micro_faqs.a: No. Dev API keys hit OpenNode's testnet stack so you can experiment with fake sats before you flip to production.

micro_faqs.q: Do I need to run a Lightning node to use OpenNode?
micro_faqs.a: OpenNode runs the channels for you, so you only manage API keys, webhooks, and payout destinations.

fees_section_title: Costs & speed: what you pay and when

fees_scenarios.title: Accept payments
fees_scenarios.what_happens: OpenNode charges a flat 1% fee on all incoming payments (both Lightning and on-chain). There are no setup, monthly, or minimum fees.
fees_scenarios.how_to_minimize: Since the fee is percentage-based, you pay less when you process less volume.

fees_scenarios.title: Withdraw Bitcoin
fees_scenarios.what_happens: Moving bitcoin to your own wallet is free if you use Lightning or scheduled weekly transfers. Instant on-chain withdrawals incur a 1% surcharge plus mining fees.
fees_scenarios.how_to_minimize: Enable scheduled weekly transfers to sweep your balance on-chain for free, or use Lightning for instant, free withdrawals.

fees_scenarios.title: Withdraw to Bank
fees_scenarios.what_happens: You can schedule daily transfers or initiate one-time wires to your bank account. OpenNode does not charge a conversion fee, but bank transfer fees apply.
fees_scenarios.how_to_minimize: Check the specific bank transfer fees in your dashboard; scheduled daily transfers may offer better rates or convenience.

fees_scenarios.title: Conversion & Settlement
fees_scenarios.what_happens: OpenNode allows you to convert between Bitcoin and local currency (like USD, EUR, GBP) instantly or at the time of transaction without any added spread or conversion fee.
fees_scenarios.how_to_minimize: Use Split Settlement to automatically hedge a portion of your revenue while keeping the rest in Bitcoin.

fees_faq.q: Are Lightning withdrawals free on OpenNode?
fees_faq.a: Yes. Instant Lightning withdrawals carry no extra fee, while on-demand on-chain withdrawals take the standard 1% plus the mining fee you select.
Weekly scheduled Bitcoin transfers are free, so you can let OpenNode sweep balances without paying the instant withdrawal fee.

key_terms.definition: An API object that contains both a BOLT11 invoice and an on-chain address so your customer can choose how to pay.
OpenNode's ready-made payment page at checkout.opennode.com/{id} that renders totals, QR codes, and status updates for you.
A Lightning withdrawal flow where OpenNode issues a QR-encoded link so wallets can pull a fixed or ranged amount of sats.

cards.title: Custody
cards.explanation: OpenNode holds funds until you withdraw or auto-settle to your wallet or bank, so their ledger is the source of truth until you sweep.

cards.title: Data Privacy
cards.explanation: Hosted checkout does not ask for personal payer data unless you collect it, which reduces the blast radius of a breach.
key_points: Payment pages need only invoice info
Webhook payloads limited to order data

cards.title: Jurisdiction & Availability
cards.explanation: OpenNode serves global merchants but unlocks features per jurisdiction once the right regulatory checks are complete.
key_points: Fiat rails limited to supported regions

cards.title: Compliance
cards.explanation: Individual accounts submit ID and a selfie, while businesses provide ownership, address, and formation records before payouts go live.

cards.title: Operational Risk
cards.explanation: You still manage API keys, callback URLs, and team permissions, so secure your credentials like production secrets.

micro_faqs.q: Can OpenNode see my customers' data?
micro_faqs.a: They only see the metadata you pass into charges, so keep invoice fields minimal if privacy matters.

micro_faqs.q: What happens if I lose dashboard access?
micro_faqs.a: Support can re-verify your identity and restore access once you provide the same KYC/KYB data used during onboarding.

integrations.intro: Drop OpenNode into your stack with plugins for stores, webhooks for automation, and APIs for payouts.

cards.title: Ecommerce plugins
cards.description: Install official plugins so customers see OpenNode checkout after they confirm the cart, without exposing API keys client-side.
steps: Install the plugin from your platform's marketplace.
Paste the API key generated in the OpenNode dashboard.
Set the success_url so orders mark paid once OpenNode posts the callback.
cards.privacy: Order data stays with your store; OpenNode only receives invoice metadata.

cards.title: API payouts
cards.description: Use /v2/withdrawals to send on-chain or Lightning payouts from your fiat or BTC balance.
steps: Wire fiat or deposit BTC into the wallet you want to draw down.
Call /v2/withdrawals with auto_confirm false to receive a quote.
Confirm the quote via the chain or Lightning endpoint before expiry.
cards.privacy: Only the payout address or invoice plus the amount leaves your environment.

cards.title: Webhooks & callbacks
cards.description: Subscribe to charge, underpayment, refund, and withdrawal events so your ERP, CRM, or fulfillment stack updates in real time.
steps: Provide a callback_url on every charge you create.
Subscribe to withdrawals webhooks so you see Lightning status changes.
Replay webhook payloads in staging to test refund logic before production.
cards.privacy: Webhooks include only the metadata you send, so do not log unnecessary customer data.

compat_explainers.why: OpenNode renders Lightning and on-chain payment options in a single checkout page, which keeps your app simple while giving customers real-time totals.
try: Create a charge in the dev environment and copy the hosted_checkout_url.
Append ?ln=1 to default to Lightning or ?hf=1 to hide fiat values.
Let OpenNode's callbacks update your order status before redirecting to your success_url.
compat_explainers.gotcha: If you exceed the Lightning amount cap, the page will fall back to on-chain only.

compat_explainers.why: You can wire fiat into OpenNode and have them convert each payout into sats on demand, so your treasury team never has to hold bitcoin.
try: Contact support to enable the fiat wallet for your jurisdiction.
Use /v2/withdrawals with wallet set to fiat to preview the FX quote.
Confirm the withdrawal and monitor the webhook for completion.
compat_explainers.gotcha: Quotes expire quickly during volatile markets, so confirm before the expiry timestamp.

compat_explainers.why: LNURL-Withdrawal lets you hand contractors or users a QR code they can scan to pull sats instantly, anchored by OpenNode's liquidity.
try: Call createLnUrlWithdrawal with matching min_amt and max_amt for fixed-value pulls.
Display the LNURL in QR form or as a link in your app.
Watch the callback_url for the lnurl_withdrawal payload to confirm success.
compat_explainers.gotcha: If the wallet does not support LNURL, provide a standard Lightning invoice fallback.

migration.title: Developer sandbox → production
migration.choose: Use this when your testnet flow is stable and you are ready for mainnet.
steps: Swap your dev API key for a production key inside the dashboard.
Update webhook URLs so production callbacks reach your live endpoints.
Run a $0.01 equivalent test payment to confirm charge and fulfillment flows.
migration.tips: Keep sandbox keys around for regression testing.
migration.gotcha: Production Lightning invoices enforce the 500000000 sat cap even if your sandbox tests exceeded it.

migration.title: BTC settlement → split or fiat
migration.choose: Use this when you want to auto-convert a percentage of every payment.
steps: Open Settings → Payments and choose split settlement.
Set the BTC percentage you want to keep versus the fiat share you want to convert.
Save and run a small charge to confirm the split posts to both wallets.
migration.tips: Document the new accounting flow so finance knows where to look for each portion.
migration.gotcha: Changes only affect new charges; historical payments keep their original settlement path.

migration.title: Rotate API keys safely
migration.choose: Use this when teammates leave or you are moving secrets to a new vault.
steps: Generate a new API key in the dashboard without deleting the old one yet.
Deploy the new key to your serverless secrets or vault.
Delete the previous key once traffic confirms the swap.
migration.tips: Schedule rotations quarterly so stale keys do not linger.
migration.gotcha: Deleting a key immediately will break plugins tied to it, so update integrations first.
